page.title: 02Hambleden Estate.
page.content: The estate has four ridges running north and south with three valleys between them.The RiverThames is situated at the base of these.At the top of the ridges there is a clay cap with beech trees.The valleys are sheltered providing warm meadows for the cows who make good use of the pasture.Halfway up the hills,the chalk breaks out and it is here that any trees growing will surely die. As the present Lord Hambleden's father died very young,the death duties were heavy and trust funds were set up.The estate of 3000 acres is leased to three farmers.Some of the fields are leased on a yearly basis so that it can be reclaimed at the end of a season.Sheep do very well in this situation.The cereal hay-day is over as efficiency has increased.
